video.title: Pokémon Coding Tutorial - CS50's Intro to Game Development
video.description:
Learn game development by creating a Pokemon clone game using Lua and LÖVE2D. The principles you learn can apply to any programming language.

This beginner's course teaches the foundations of game development. This video is lecture 7 of CS50's Intro to Game Development from Harvard University.

Check out the full course playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbluXJKKbCIb4xd7fcRkpzoz

🔗https://docs.cs50.net/ocw/games/assignments/7/assignment7.html

⭐️Contents⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:04:59) Pokémon Demo
⌨️ (0:11:33) StateStack
⌨️ (0:20:32) StartState
⌨️ (0:23:32) FadeInState
⌨️ (0:29:22) DialogueState
⌨️ (0:33:23) PlayState
⌨️ (0:36:11) Grid-Aligned Movement
⌨️ (0:42:25) Dialogue Revisited
⌨️ (0:44:13) Level
⌨️ (0:46:13) Triggering Encounters
⌨️ (0:50:09) GUIs
⌨️ (0:52:36) 9-Patches
⌨️ (0:55:10) GUI Widgets
⌨️ (1:01:46) Panel
⌨️ (1:03:25) Textbox
⌨️ (1:08:49) Selection
⌨️ (1:12:16) Menu
⌨️ (1:12:50) Party and Pokemon
⌨️ (1:22:19) BattleSprite
⌨️ (1:23:58) Shaders
⌨️ (1:28:45) BattleState
⌨️ (1:37:55) BattleMenuState
⌨️ (1:43:06) TakeTurnState
⌨️ (1:56:10) In Conclusion

Lecture taught by Colton T. Ogden. Thanks to Harvard's CS50 for giving us permission to post this lecture. Checkout their YouTube channel for more great lectures: https://www.youtube.com/cs50

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

replies.author: Justin Blair
replies.text:
Something I just thought of, to add: 

The game in the video is a Pokemon clone.  This is something you're thinking of doing.  He's not selling this game, so he shouldn't be getting a copyright violation.  

So, as I said in the previous post, if this is strictly for your personal enjoyment and learning, you should be fine.  I'd still ask an expert (a lawyer), just in case.

replies.author: Justin Blair
replies.text:
It's a little slippery.  They mention DQ and FF in the video; on the surface, they're close to the same game.  Same with that PT horror game and all the "clones" that came after it.  So, it can be confusing as to what's OK and what isn't. 

From my understanding (and to be transparent, I'm no expert), if you were to make your game as described for yourself to play at home, you should be fine.  If you try to sell the game, you might run into trouble (copyright infringement, for example).

If you plan on selling it, you should think of something to make it even slightly different from Pokemon.  Not necessarily cosmetic, but some kind of mechanic that would truly separate it from Pokemon.  But to be safe, you really should consult a lawyer that specializes in this field.  A patent lawyer, for example.

topLevelComment.author: DeepFriedOreo
topLevelComment.text: I don't think the tile-based design of Pokemon was simply based on how much easier it is to design. Keep in mind that Nintendo has always had strong hierarchical chain of command, and the movement in Pokemon was, already at the time, a staple of other turn-based RPGs like Final Fantasy, Dragon Warrior/Quest, and others on the NES.

replies.text: @Greg Mark You clearly didn't read my comment, that's what I said, in many less words lol. It's the sprites.

replies.author: Greg Mark
replies.text: @DeepFriedOreo Yeah, the problem is not storing the state of the world, it's storing the graphics. Using tiled graphics saves thousands of kbytes. Put it this way: a full Gameboy screen is 8k. How many screens does the entire Pokemon map take up? Multiply that times 8k for the total memory needed, and I think you get a number much larger the available storage on a Gameboy. With tiles, you can have a bunch of very large maps without using very much storage. Tiled graphics amount to a very effective form of data compression. Otoh, I'm not discounting the appeal of their simplicity. Ijs, on consoles back in the early 90s, storage was incredibly limited. Pretty much every design decision was heavily influenced by that factor.
